awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Secondary Active Membrane Transporters: Determining Protein Structure and Transport Mechanisms with a New Hybrid Simulation
awd_abstract_narration:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT 
Cell membranes are a crucial component of all biological organisms. They can protect the cell or compartments within a cell that have their own membranes from harmful compounds. Membrane transport proteins that span cell membranes can act as gatekeepers that control the influx of helpful molecules and enable the efflux of harmful molecules. Membrane transport proteins are grouped into classes based on their function; one such class, secondary active transporters (SATs), is of specific interest to this project. SATs couple the movement of a small primary substrate (protons or ions) to that of a larger substrate (sugars, amino acids, peptides). These proteins use the energy gain from the downhill movement (high to low concentration) of the primary substrate to facilitate the uphill movement (low to high concentration) of a larger substrate. Although atomic-level structures have been determined for several SATs, for a given protein typically only a single conformation in the transport cycle is known. However, transport of substrates involves significant protein structural changes that are not captured by a single conformation. The main objective of this research is to investigate the transport mechanisms and multiple protein conformational changes of several SATs with atomic-level simulations. A new atomic resolution simulation approach known as "implicit-explicit membrane simulation" will be used to enhance conformational sampling while preserving the natural transition between conformational states in SATs. Initially, this new method will be tested on the sodium-hydantoin transporter (Mhp1) because several structures in its transport cycle have been determined from x-ray diffraction. In collaboration with experimentalists, transitions between Mhp1 conformations facing inside and outside the cell will be researched, as will possible mutations that stabilize new structures, such as the inward-facing occluded structure. Studies on Mhp1 will lay the groundwork for using this new method on other SATs, especially those with only a single known protein conformation, such as lactose permease. This new simulation tool ultimately will allow studies of previously unknown transport cycle states in SATs and give experimental structural biologists insight into how these states may be stabilized. Moreover, studies of these SATs may lead to better understanding of how similar proteins in mammals, plants, and single-celled organisms transport substrates and change conformations.

BROADER IMPACTS 
High school instructional aids will be developed to promote active student engagement and interest in molecular biology. Specifically, an educational website will be developed that focuses on three general topics, namely, proteins, cell membranes, and function of membrane proteins. This website will include text, figures, movies, and interactive applets that describe each topic. In addition, this project will continue the development of a joint undergraduate and graduate course, Molecular Modeling Methods, intended to introduce students to chemical and biomolecular aspects of molecular simulation methods. Additionally, undergraduate and graduate students, particularly those from backgrounds underrepresented in research, will be recruited for training in computational biology techniques. Key to these educational goals is proper assessment of the impact of the educational website, teaching and mentoring. Collaboration with an educational researcher experienced in developing educational tools, assessments, and questionnaires will aid in fulfilling these educational goals. Overall, implementing this educational plan will increase high school students interest in STEM careers, promote interest in computational biology, and train the next generation of science and engineering researchers.

This project is jointly supported by the Cellular Processes Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
This NSF CAREER grant focused on researching proteins involved in small molecule transport across the cell as well as other projects modeling cell membranes. This research was also extended to disseminate the ideas to the public through the development of an on-line tool set for the education of high-school and undergraduate students with movies made from our molecular modeling research. Overall, this project produced a total of 35 peer-reviewed research papers (likely 47 after others are accepted for publication), and educated a total of one high school student, 16 undergraduate students, 4 graduate students, and 1 postdoctoral fellow. Specific areas of research and findings are as follows:

1.Determined that a certain enhanced sampling method (IM-EX MS with SGLD) was not able to accurately predict structural changes in SAT proteins

2.Investigated the sugar transport mechanism for a semi-SWEET transport protein

3.Aided in interpreting low-resolution experimental measures (DEER) of structural changes of another sugar transporter (lactose permease)

4.Investigated the mechanism for PlexinA3 homodimerization and how the transmembrane and near membrane association is important to the function of this protein in regulating growth

5.Probing the mechanism for a lipid packing sensor peptide important in a protein to its function for lipid exchange within the cell

6.Further tested and validated our lipid force field model for a range of various lipids and temperature conditions against x-ray neutron and NMR experimental measurements

7.Developed new all-atom force fields to do simulations for sphingolipids and ceramides along with a lower resolution united-atom chain model for lipids

8.Developed models and structural insight into the condensed phases (gel and ripple) for saturated acyl chained lipids

9.Studied the destabilizing effect of ethanol on model bilayers

10.Probed the structural and dynamical behavior of model membranes of sphingolipids and other lipids for simple models for the plasma membrane

11.Simulated model membranes of the cytoplasmic membrane of E. coli in different stages of the colony life cycle

12.Develop models for the complex structure of the outer layer of the skin (stratum corneum)

13.Develop model membranes of the plasma membrane for the soy seedling

14.Develop model membranes of the ocular lens membrane

15.Develop a complex model for the plasma membrane and trans-Golgi of yeast

16.Developed a design and initial examples for our on-line educational toolset (https://eng.umd.edu/~jbklauda/NSF-Website/index.php)

17.Developed an on-line Wiki page for our lab but also freely available to other researchers to aid in setting up and analyzing membrane simulations (https://eng.umd.edu/~jbklauda/wiki/doku.php)


Last Modified: 10/25/2018
Modified by: Jeffery B Klauda
